Fields.DialogueText: We need these supplies loaded as quickly as possible.
Sawubona, Captain.
Hello to you, too, Zulu. Sorry if I'm short with the pleasantries today, but I'm anxious about how long this resupply is taking.
No need to apologize. The latest intelligence reports would give even the bravest of us cause for concern.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not scared.
You're nervous, too?
And I would know! I'm the bravest of us out here!

Fields.DialogueText: Goodness! Forgive me, Captain, but I never meant to suggest that. I only meant that the reports carry a significant threat to the region.
I'll put it this way - we should all take heed of the threat.
Ha! I'd never suggest otherwise, Captain, but we should still be cautious.
If HQ is right, we can expect heavy Morgana resistance to our patrols and some... unprecedented behavior.
Enough chit-chat for now. Get our supplies aboard promptly, and let's get out to sea.
Aye-aye, Captain. The sooner we're away from port, the better.
Shapes in the water, starboard quarter!
Did you hear that, Captain?
I did. Push off from the supply ship and get the crew to battle stations, Zulu!
@BATTLE
Close call, but our luck held. The locals got away without a scratch.
Glad to hear it.
Hard enough finding support vessels as it is, Captain. Losing good ones to Morganas would be a damn shame on top of that.

Fields.MenuText: It takes guts to sail an unarmed vessel into a combat zone.
I wouldn't blame a civilian ship for being scared to help.
They support us so that we can fight. We all have our part in this.

Fields.DialogueText: Guts... or they're touched in the head.
What choice do they really have? Tie up to a pier and wait for the whole war to end?
Amen to that, Skipper.
That's why I wanted to serve on a destroyer. Assignment to a ship with a Belle? Even better.
Now that you mention it, have you seen the Lady of the House? Zulu's been scarce lately.
Can't say that I have, Captain. If I do cross her path, should I ask her to find you?
I'm sure that she'll--
*RUMBLE*
Whoa!
You felt that, too?
Nearly lost my balance...
*RUMBLE*
No mistaking it that time!
I'm on my way to the bridge.
Aye-aye, Captain!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Are you sure you won't sit down? You must be--
In pain? A little, but I think I'd rather stay on my feet for now, Captain.
We all felt the rumbling and shaking--
And you're certain that none of the crew were hurt?
Absolutely. I checked again with the ship's doctor today. Nobody came to sick call with injuries.
I'm grateful for that. At least I can take some relief from knowing my people are safe.
We hit something in the water pretty hard...
Running over a seamount or even a sandbar can devastate a warship making way at full speed.

Fields.MenuText: At least we didn't get stuck.
I'm still concerned about the integrity of our hull.
Think it might have been a submerged contact?

Fields.DialogueText: I take no small relief from that, too. I have no interest in being dead in the water.
You would be the first person to know if I thought we had sprung a leak.
You mean a submarine? Doubtful. I felt a rumble instead of a bang, which convinces me that I dragged my hull over land.
Please inform the navigator to mark our charts with a possible seamount at that location. I'd hate for other ships to hit that spot, too.
Already done. I sent a priority message to HQ warning them about the hazard.
Sure you won't take that seat? No shame in taking a rest, Zulu.
I might need a bed more than I need a chair, Captain. If you don't mind, I might retire to my quarters for a bit.
*ALARM*
Damn...
*sigh*
Are you--
It will have to wait. I won't let the crew down!
I'll take you at your word, Zulu... but once we give the all clear, I want you in bed.
Aye-aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
Part of a Morgana tactic, you think? Maybe that Bitch Fleet is getting really clever.
What do you mean?
Like laying a trap, Lieutenant.
You're mistaken, Petty Officer.
Lady Zulu said we didn't run into a mine or a net; we ran over a naturally occurring shallow spot in the ocean.
A seamount or some shoal water gets the job done, all the same.
I still don't see what you're getting at, sailor.

Fields.MenuText: A natural hazard provides an opportunity, Lieutenant.
Are the Morganas really that clever?
The Morganas are... building underwater mountains for us to crash into?! Genius!

Fields.DialogueText: That's what I've been trying to tell him, Skipper!  Err....
Morganas are a crafty lot, Captain. I'd put nothing past 'em.
I hope that's a joke, Skipper. I really do hope so...
Now I understand. Your theory is--
Theory?! I'm no fancy scientist, Lieutenant!
Ahem.
Your theory is that the Morganas might know about shallow spots in the water that we don't... so if a ship like us happens to run aground on it...
... then that same unlucky ship might get stuck, or at least crippled. Easy pickings for the Bitch Fleet!
Ahem.
Er, ''the BF'' is what I meant to say.
Do you really think the Morganas are watching every single ship that...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Easy, sailor, we're all under tension here.
Are you sure that you're up for this?
I got plenty of rest before the meeting, Captain. I can finish.
If it helps, Captain, I could have minutes from the remainder of our brief forwarded to Lady Zulu's cabin afterwards.
Pardon me for saying so, Lieutenant, but I'd rather focus our attention upon matters at hand.
Oh.
Didn't mean anything by it. I didn't mean to exclude you or sound dismissive, ma'am.

Fields.MenuText: The lieutenant is just trying to be considerate.
She wouldn't be here if she wasn't up for it, Lieutenant.
Good point. Want to sit the rest of this one out, Zulu?

Fields.DialogueText: I took no offense, Captain.
As I said, I'm rested and ready to work.
Cha, ngiyabonga. I do not, Captain.
Actually, we've covered everything we needed to discuss. Lieutenant, verify the ammunition count for the guns.
Now?
It sounded like an order when I gave it.
Aye-aye, Captain.
We didn't cover the navigation updates or the shore support exercises yet.
Get yourself a little more rest. I know you're still shaken from hitting that seamount, and I need you in top shape.
Was my discomfort so obvious? I wanted to avoid showing weakness in front of the wardroom or the crew.
You haven't lost anybody's confidence, Zulu. Especially not mine.
If Morganas come looking for weakness, I'm happy to show them what my guns can do!
@BATTLE
HEY! Pass that wrench down here!
I hear a damn pair of boots stomping on my deck plates! Somebody's lollygaggin' around up there!
A box wrench or a pipe wrench, chief? I see a lot of tools adrift here in the engine room.
Stand fast, pup. I'm climbing up.
Attention on deck!
As you were, Chief.
Curse my lips, Captain, I never meant no disrespect on ya. Just a little bit of a tangle down here that my snipes are tryin' to get sorted out.
And, ah, I'll get these tools stowed right away...

Fields.MenuText: First time I heard of any trouble back here. What are you working on, Chief?
I appreciate vigour, Chief. A little professionalism goes a long way, too.
Let's hop down and turn some wrenches. I could use a break from paperwork.

Fields.DialogueText: A few headers are out of whack, and what we can't peen over we've gotta bend or reroute.
Didn't know it was you up here, honest! Apologies, Cap. Just a bit of frustration with the troubles down here.
After my own heart, Cap, but I know you've got bigger obligations than banging away in the bilges.
No surprise the ship's Lady doesn't complain about it. She's tough as nails, that one.
She's hiding how much that accident really hurt her. How bad is it, really?
Ehhhhh... it's mostly bluster and such, Cap. My snipes can get the worst of it under control.
Sure you don't need me to turn a wrench with you?
*ALARM*
Maybe that's your answer. Get those boots to the bridge, Cap!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Not too late to change course, Captain. You sure that you want to do this?
Steady as she goes, Chief.
Aye-aye, Captain. Hope you've got enough room on your desk.
*SLAM*
That's all of it. Every technical drawing with the notes of the work we've been doing in the engine room since the, uh...

Fields.MenuText: Since the grounding?
Since the damage.
Since you... yelled at me to give you a wrench?

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, that.
The damage that my snipes have worked hard to fix, Cap.
Ha! Got me there. I was referring to our scrape with a seamount, though.
Right. Well, it's mostly sorted now. A few pipes and some dents still in need of constructive abuse. Maybe a patch or two still to do, too, but the bilges are finally dry.
Good. So I just need to do a little light reading.
Need a stiff cup of black tea to keep you awake through all that? I could flog a steward to bring you some.
I've already got a cup, thanks. No need to flog anybody.
Let me know if you change your mind! Flogging's one of my favorites.
You know that was outlawed in the 19th century, Chief?
Oh? Maybe I've got some reading to catch up on, too. Got a spare book of regulations I could borrow.
You're making a joke, right?
*ALARM*
That sound ain't no joke!
No time to read. Are we going to hold up to hard maneuvers, Chief?
Maybe a few clangs and bangs, and honestly sometimes we can just... we can tell she's in some pain... but our snipes do good work. Zulu's got us, Cap.
Good. Keep the steam coming strong until the gunfire stops.
@BATTLE
Strength I appreciate. Firepower. Accuracy. Speed. Smart maneuvers.
I aim to deliver, Captain.
Professionalism, mutual respect up and down the chain of command...
Yes...
Let's throw cleanliness into the bucket, too.
Um... into the bucket it goes, Captain. Why are you telling me this?
Something is missing.

Fields.MenuText: Honesty.
Sacrifice.
A bravo opening number! I'm a sucker for great choreography, too.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't disagree with that.
You know that I'd sacrifice anything for this crew, Captain.
I may be Zulu, but I've got as much of a British sense of humor as the next girl. Whatever this joke is about, I'm at a loss, Captain.
Also, are you calling me a "bucket?"
I need you to be forthright with me about the extent of the damage. When we struck the bottom, the damage was...
... more severe than I let on.
Exactly. That one hit the target.
I wouldn't endanger us, Captain. Just some aches and pains, and I don't want the crew to get the wrong idea.
I'm not sure that--
*ALARM*
This conversation isn't over, Zulu.
You'll always find me ready, Captain. Just like my guns!
@BATTLE
Don't hold back, sailor. If you need to use a full rudder, use the full rudder.
If you say so, Lady Zulu.
You don't seem convinced yet.
No disrespect, but it's no big secret, ma'am. We've all noticed...
Noticed what?
Noticed that...

Fields.MenuText: Noticed that full rudders at full speed can make the crew seasick.
Noticed that the rudder response was a bit sluggish.
(I'll let him handle this one...)

Fields.DialogueText: Is that really true? Honestly, you have no need to deflect the situation, Captain.
You could sense that?
It's all right, sailor. Be truthful, please.
We still make the turns, and we still get the speed when the Officer of the Deck orders a bell, but...
... it feels like it hurts you.
Oh. I didn't think you would be able to tell. Ngiyabonga - for being candid.
I'm fully capable, thanks to a lot of hard work from damage control, but it does sometimes hurt when I exert myself.
Oh. Is there something we should be doing different?
Cha. Nothing at all.
Zulu, can I speak to you in private?
Not yet... we've got company.
They're like damn sharks. Why won't they leave us alone?
Lock it up, sailor. We've got a fight coming.
@BATTLE
Well, it's hard to explain how I can sense it...
I can see you've still got your lights on in your cabin. If you aren't going to sleep, then do you have time to talk?
Come in, Captain. If you must know, I just woke up from a nap.
Glad to hear you got some sleep. Ready for some good news?
Yebo! Did HQ send us updated intelligence on Morgana behaviour in the Mediterranean Sea?
No. HQ doesn't have anything new for us yet.
Actually, I was going to say that HQ is negotiating drydock schedules to get you overhauled.
Oh...

Fields.MenuText: Thought you'd be relieved to get repairs scheduled.
Too proud to get fixed?
A simple "thank you" or even a "ngiyabonga" would be appropriate....

Fields.DialogueText: I am...
That's not the problem, Captain.
Ngiyabonga, Captain. I don't mean to appear ungrateful.
But I don't like the idea of spending time away from the war effort. Remaining operational and useful is important to me.
How useful can you be if you're in pain? Rest is important. I've heard sailors in the American fleet, they say, "When the ship that is tired returneth..."
"When the ship that is tired returneth, With signs of the sea showing plain, Men place her in dock for a season..."
"And her speed reneweth again."
It was a British admiral who wrote that, by the way. Hopwood. Not an American.
It's still good advice, Zulu.
Drydock or not, my engines will always give you my best speed. Pain or not, I'll still fight... with full effectiveness.
Understood. But once HQ has an available drydock for us, we're taking it.
Yebo, Captain.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain on the bridge!
As you were. Any problems on your watch, Lieutenant?
The navigator's weather reports were accurate... unfortunately. Poor visibility the whole watch, I'm afraid.
Don't be afraid. Drive the ship accordingly. What's your ordered course to the helmsman, Lieutenant?
Our track is... damn! We're drifting off.
Mind your helm, sailor! I ordered course zero-three-six, not zero-four-three. I expect you to steer the ordered course.
I know what "mind your helm" means...

Fields.MenuText: Shut your trap and steer the damn course. I didn't authorize insubordination on this ship.
Acknowledge the order and follow it.
Why is everybody in a daze?

Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye, Captain.
Coming left to course zero-three-six.
Honestly, I'm ashamed to admit it, but I hadn't noticed until you came up here. Maybe it's this hazy weather.
Maybe it's something else. Where the heck is Zulu?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Any chance we'll see some supplies soon? I wouldn't mind a bit of milk that hasn't gone sour.
Milk? Usually I hear the crew grumble about these things before I hear you complain about it.
Not a complaint, Captain, but it would help this cup of tea go down.
Still unusual behavior for you. Is that... sniff...
Can you smell that from where you're standing? I didn't think the herbs were that strong.

Fields.MenuText: I'm afraid to ask. Please tell me it's legal.
This might explain a few things I've observed recently.
Is it a remedy for your pain?

Fields.DialogueText: I promise you, Captain, that even though I'm trying some traditional Zulu remedies, I'm mindful of British law.
Oh?
Yebo, and the medicine seems to be working.
Is it... a problem? I'm still performing at full capacity, but this helps with some of the pain.
I'm sympathetic, Zulu. That grounding would have sent just about any other ship limping home at two knots. Or to the bottom of the sea.
And yet?
I might be crazy, but I think it somehow... affects the whole crew, too.
Sigh... it makes a strange sort of sense. Especially if they've had no chance to build up a tolerance.
Do what you can to minimize the dose, until we can get you to a drydock. I need you capable, but I need the crew focused, too.
Aye-aye, Captain. We both want the same thing – keeping this whole ship ready for a fight.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Ngiyabonga, Chief. Please pass my appreciation to your mechanics for such a wonderful job on those propulsion bearings.
My pleasure to tell 'em so, Lady Zulu.
Hello, Cap. Taking a tour back aft? You've picked a good time for it.
Agreed. Chief diagnosed a few bearings that were causing trouble and fixed them. I can feel the difference already.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like Chief is trying to butter you up.
Proper lubrication oil flow at the bearings is critical for propulsion. Glad we caught that in time.
Was it like arthritis?

Fields.DialogueText: Lube oil would taste terrible on bread, Captain.
Yebo, Captain.
I've never had arthritis, so I couldn't accurately compare the sensation. I'm not that old, Captain!
Squeakin' and squawkin' in the engine room... well that's music to nobody's ears, ma'am.
Keep up the great work, Chief. If Zulu's happy, we're all better off.
Aye-aye, Cap.
Zulu, what's the matter?
Now that I can ''hear'' more clearly, I can sense... Morganas, Captain.
It's a long walk back to the bridge – let's not waste any time!
@BATTLE
I'd rather eat liver...
*ALARM*
Before we start the strategy brief, did both of you review the reports I specified?
Yebo, Captain.
The reports were... a bit of a strange collection. Why make us review sick bay records and maintenance summaries before a combat strategy meeting?
Can you see a correlation, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Yes... but I didn't see the relationship until recently.
I hoped we'd find a correlation together.
None whatsoever. I just hate paperwork and wanted you to share in my misery.

Fields.DialogueText: That might confirm my own theory, Captain. Care to explain?
Good instincts, Captain. Your collection of reports all pointed me to the same answer. Morganas attacked when we appeared weak.
Fun or not, the paperwork paid off. Your... sadism helped me put the pieces together. Observation.
The Morganas read signs of our vulnerability.
So... just simple reconnaissance? Collecting intelligence? I'm failing to see the significance here.
The Morganas are watching us more carefully than we realize? More intelligently?
More than that. We unwittingly gave them signs.
Oh! Like when we all sensed that Lady Zulu was in pain... but she never talked or complained about it.
Hoped you wouldn't notice, but... you all did. And when I used too much of some traditional painkiller herbs in my tea--
We all felt that one! And I think the Morganas noticed, too.
So how do we better protect ourselves? How do we get smarter about all this?
Cha!
No?
I have a MUCH better idea than that...
*ALARM*
Don't forget what it is! Meet back here after we deal with these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Simple observation.
Explain it to me again, Lieutenant. Morganas are watching us like hawks, and--
More like wolves. Or lions. That's how Lady Zulu explained it.
Whatever, Captain. Predators. And we're the fluffy little animals, bouncing all around.
Right.
We're a bloody destroyer, if you'll pardon my enthusiasm. Not a fluffy little bunny!

Fields.MenuText: You're missing the point, Lieutenant.
You're missing the point, sailor.
You two idiots should pay attention to driving the ship.

Fields.DialogueText: Just trying to explain our tactics, Captain.
Been trying my best to make it clear, Captain.
But you said--
Let me explain this to you. Predators attack when their prey looks vulnerable. We've given off signs of vulnerability, especially since we ran aground.
Morganas could see it. Nothing magical, just observation.
But Chief told us we're patched up. Lady Zulu said so, too. We're seaworthy, right?
Of course we are--
If your mission was to dispel my confusion, Lieutenant, call HQ. Tell 'em you failed.
Knock it off, both of you. My orders stand. Drive this ship with smart precision.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Amen. If it keeps Morganas off our backs, I'll do it. Whatever it is.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Morgana contacts coming over the horizon, Captain.
And the German submarine?
Still off the port quarter, maintaining course and speed.
She'd better. If she deviates from the plan, she's well within range of my guns.
Zurich Agreement, ma'am. When the Morganas are defeated, THEN we can try to kill each other.
I'd like to see her try!

Fields.MenuText: Me, too. How important is the Zurich Agreement, anyway?
Easy on the trigger, Zulu. We can't risk the only treaty that's keeping us allied against the Morganas.
Enough! Follow my orders.

Fields.DialogueText: Ngiyabonga, Captain... but you don't have to tease me. I won't violate the agreement.
I wouldn't dare, Captain, unless that German submarine tries to stab us in the back.
Aye-aye, Captain.
I want you to observe the Morganas, and that German submarine, carefully.
They're watching us closely, too.
She just took her flags down, Captain... and we have a report from Radio.
The German sub just radioed us her intention to dive before commencing her attack on the Morgana targets.
No deck gun from her, then. Just torpedoes. My guns are ready, Captain. And I'm saving one for the Germans, just in case.
See those plumes? She's venting her ballast tanks to dive, just like she said.
Time it. This is our chance to see just how quickly they can execute a dive.
Good thinking, Lady Zulu!
That's exactly what I want, careful observation. And one more thing.
It looks like the Germans are going to cooperate, at least to some point. Still, we count on ourselves to get the job done.
Agreed.
Flank speed, Zulu. Commence the attack.
@BATTLE
I couldn't see any hits on the Morganas that we didn't inflict ourselves.
Not a trace of her after the fight.
Shall I transmit a request to Berlin for that submarine's after-action report?
Ha! Point taken, Captain... but why are you smiling?
I learned something from that fight.

Fields.MenuText: German submarine batteries have much better endurance than I realized.
It took less than a minute for the German submarine to dive before the fight.
Coordinating with a submarine we don't fully trust hindered our attack.

Fields.DialogueText: True! She was under a long time, and didn't surface until she was beyond our visual detection range.
I didn't want to trip over her torpedoes... if she even fired any to help us out!
Useful enough for me to send back to HQ. I'll include that in my report, along with our usual Morgana information from the fight.
Anything else on your mind, Zulu? Your performance was excellent.
I wonder what the Morganas could see. I wonder what they observe and report about us...
Interesting... but don't let curiosity become paranoia, all right?
Agreed.
@BATTLE
Fifty-eight seconds.
Oh? I've seen them dive in as little as thirty. They were holding back.
Find what you were looking for in that report?
Not even from that German sub?
Oh?
*ALARM*
Left ten degrees rudder. Steady on one-three-five.
One-three-five, aye, ma'am. Steady on course...
You had something else to say?
How did--?
Your posture. I could tell you were thinking something, so why not ask?
It crossed my mind to say that... we're handling much better. Easier to keep the ship on course.
Ah.

Fields.MenuText: Zulu's stopped using so much of that herbal supplement in her black tea. We've all got clearer heads.
Chief's repairs are keeping Zulu in good shape.
Zulu reads you like a book!

Fields.DialogueText: I haven't exactly stopped... just reduced the dose a bit.
I'd do better with another overhaul in drydock, but I'm glad we can stave that off for now.
Wasn't trying to be rude, just staying observant.
Fine by me.
Oh, I was just thinking...
*WHOOSH*
Whoa! My rudder! We're heeling over to starboard, Captain!
Don't panic, I just took control for a moment.
I'll trust you have a good reason...
There. Have a look.
Oh! Dark smoke coming up, over the horizon? Those are...
Morganas, firing up their engines to flank speed to pursue us.
What?!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I just had a conversation with a thoroughly unhappy supply officer. The cooks have been cursing your name, apparently.
Hardly surprising, considering how often I criticize their attempts to make a decent liver and onions for supper.
Not this time. You spooked them with your surprise maneuvers... heeling us over with your dramatic turns made a huge mess in the galley.
Honestly, I'm sympathetic.  I don't like wasting food or people's time, but the maneuver was valuable. You saw what happened, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Our ship executed a high-speed turn. We proved we can do it.
When you suddenly turned, Morganas thought you had spotted them.
You splattered some bad food onto the bulkheads, and taught the cooks they should be ready for anything.

Fields.DialogueText: We proved more than that. Let me explain my thinking to you, Captain.
Exactly!
A side effect, but an unintentional one, I promise.
Operating with that German submarine, I imagined that I might be in her crosshairs. Well, not crosshairs, exactly... but in a firing solution for a torpedo.
Hard, random maneuvers would spoil their ability to line up a shot.
I felt the Morganas might be watching me, and wanted to spoil their aim...
And they blundered, revealing themselves by speeding up to catch us on a new intercept course.
Right.
So... a healthy... paranoia?
We know the Morganas were watching. Can't deny that. And it gave me a few other ideas, too.
Good ones, I hope, but you need to make things right with the cooks.
Aye-aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
After this battle.
Not often that I get called up to your stateroom, Captain.
I needed a spare typewriter ribbon, and I figured you might have one back aft.
Fair assessment, Cap. Here's the ribbon. Plenty of ink on it. I'm more comfortable with a pencil, myself.
Also, I'm sure you didn't want me to stop by for another reason. Probably just figured I had nothing else to do, right?

Fields.MenuText: I just thought you could use the exercise.
Sorry... I should've gotten a messenger instead of bothering a chief to fetch my office supplies.
Start gossiping, Chief. Why else would I ask you up here?

Fields.DialogueText: You wouldn't be wrong about that, Cap.
Think nothin' of it, Cap. Happy to make the trip myself.
That's what I thought.
As long as I happen to be in this neck of the woods, Cap, I'd say Zulu's in fair shape. The repairs my snipes made? They're holding, but that's not all that keeps her together.
She's strong. All those crazy maneuvers and stunts she pulls? She handles the strain just fine. Maybe she don't even need a trip to the drydock, if yer askin' me.
Glad to hear it.
So... doing a lot of typing then?
Huh?
Typewriter ribbon. Remember?
Drafting a request to HQ. If Zulu's in good condition, and HQ approves my request, then we're going to have a few more crazy maneuvers coming up.
We'll keep turning wrenches, Cap. Just ask for more steam, and you'll get it.
Thanks, Chief.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Speaking of which...
You've excused the rest of the wardroom. Something you wanted to discuss in confidence, Captain?
I sent a full report to HQ about our patrol. Morgana engagements, coordinated ops with a German sub, your careful observations...
Those insights were a collaborative effort.
Credit where it's due, Zulu.
HQ sent these. Start reading.
Ngiyabonga, Captain. What's this?
Mission orders. I wanted you to see them before we brief the rest of the wardroom.
A major op, based on our assessment of Morgana intelligence collection. We're leading an armed merchant convoy to lure Morganas into a trap.
Why do you think they assigned us for the mission?

Fields.MenuText: Our research, so we get the honors.
We coordinated with a secretive German sub, we can coordinate with anybody.
Maybe HQ thinks the Morganas are following us, and that will draw attention to the convoy.

Fields.DialogueText: Yebo, I see the logic of it. If we are needed, I'm ready.
I'd rather lead a gaggle of panicked merchant ships than work with that German submarine again. I'm ambivalent about German ships in general, but...
Morganas will attack any target that seems weak. I am NOT weak.
Only one thing about this operation disturbs me. I don't like using civilian ships as Morgana bait.
No need to worry about that.
Oh?
Of course not. We're the bait.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Noted. But dial it back.
Whoa! Am I following this rightly, Cap? You want me to weld a bypass around the filters? We'll make so much smoke we'll darken the skies!
That's exactly what we want. When I give the signal, make us look like we've sustained a major propulsion casualty.
All part of the big plan, eh? I'll hafta work fast. It will take me some time to rig the flapper valves just right, so we can restore full propulsion when we need it.
Get started right away. Dismissed.
So, we fake an injury and... the convoy just leaves us behind?
No, Lieutenant...
Thank goodness!
... We're leaving them behind. I won't be able to protect them.
All part of the plan, Lady Zulu. The merchants have enough support without us to make it to safety. The key is...

Fields.MenuText: ... to make it look like our propulsion really failed. Morganas will take the easy target.
... to show the Morganas wobbly maneuvers like we're really hurt. We have to convince them.
... don't go down too easily. We can't fake a knockout from just one punch.

Fields.DialogueText: Like wolves. Or vultures.
I'll keep my rudder sluggish, like I've had too much medicinal tea.
Most of the Morganas can't shoot effectively. That might be the hardest part of the illusion, if you ask me!
Then we transmit a distress call. Encrypted.
I disagree. How will the Morganas intercept the message if they don't know our codes? Send unencoded messages they can understand.
They don't have to understand. They just have to see accurate behavior. They'll guess what the messages mean, even if they can't break the code.
Yebo... because that's what we would do if the emergency were real. Clever...
All merchants report that they're ready to go, Captain. Shall I tell them we're ready?
Send the signal. We're getting underway now. Take station at the front of the convoy.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Our reinforcements. How long will it take them to arrive?
They're waiting at a long standoff distance, so that the Morganas won't detect them. Expect to be on our own for a while.
I see.
*Gulp*
@BATTLE
Vultures...
*ALARM*
Maybe I expected a little more resistance. Morganas haven't taken a real bite at us... yet.
We'll be most vulnerable in a few moments. I'd expect an ambush there.
Coming up on the narrows now, Captain.
Once the shooting starts, be ready for my signal. Chief will blow black smoke, and we'll fall behind the convoy.
Aye-aye, Captain.
One of the merchants just reported... fast-moving ships not conforming to the traffic scheme.
Here we go!
@BATTLE
Fought them off, Captain, but they're regrouping for another go at our convoy.

Fields.MenuText: We should just fight them here, no tricks. Why wait for reinforcements when we can beat them now?
Time to execute our plan.
What are we doing again?

Fields.DialogueText: I recommend sticking to our plan and luring them in. The Morganas won't fully commit unless we look like easy prey.
We're ready.
Pretending that we're hurt, so the Morganas will be lured to an overconfident attack. Were you testing me, Captain?
Lieutenant, tell the engine room to blow black smoke. Zulu, time to--
Time to play hurt. Aye-aye, Captain. Cutting our propulsion and our maneuverability. Captain, you do realize that--
That we'll be hit by a lot more gunfire if we can't evade? I do, Zulu. That's the hazard, but we'll trust ourselves and our reinforcements.
I won't let them sink us, Captain.
Good point. I forgot about that.
Just making sure, Zulu.
*ALARM*
We're a bit sluggish turning to port, Captain.
I'm not sure that--
Lady Zulu must be pulling her "lame duck" trick again.  Leave it to her to pull those Morganas in tight!
And the Morganas bought it, hook, line, and... woah....
All of them did... ALL the Morganas... So many more of them....
Now we keep throwing punches until our reinforcements arrive.
@BATTLE
Drove 'em back for now...
At a price. They're not playing nice, Captain.
We just have to keep them off a little longer, Lieutenant.
C-Captain...
Talk to me, Zulu!
Ngisize, Captain... I... hurt all over... Ubuhlungu...

Fields.MenuText: Look alive! You only have to fool the Morganas, not the whole crew!
I think she's hurt...
Bravo! So convincing! If I didn't know better, I'd think you were dying!

Fields.DialogueText: Zulu's collapsed... Helmsman, carry Zulu to her quarters.
But my station...
That rudder's gone, sailor. Lady Zulu got us this far, and we'll finish the fight from here.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Keep the guns alive, Lieutenant. We're not done yet.
Captain, look! More smoke... reinforcements!
Second wave incoming!
*ALARM*
Cup of tea? Needed to stretch my legs, and I felt like having tea with somebody.
Thanks, Zulu. Thoughtful of you!
Least I could do. I'll admit, I'm still embarrassed that I missed the good part of the battle.
For the hundredth time, Zulu, the battle was over the moment before you collapsed.  You did the heavy lifting, don't doubt it!
Ah, yes! Bait for Morgana target practice. It worked... and then I passed out.
You didn't miss much... just the part when three task forces sailed in to our ''rescue'' and blasted Morgana vultures over the horizon.
Reading the after-action reports is never as good as witnessing something first-hand.
You did great, Zulu.
Oh, wait! Before you pour any tea...
Problem with it?

Fields.MenuText: Is this your special medicinal tea? I don't want to fall asleep at my desk.
Do we have anything besides tea?
Tea's great, but we should have a pint or two sometime.

Fields.DialogueText: Cha. You've got nothing to fear, Captain. I'm weaning myself from that remedy.
I'm British, Captain! What else is there to drink?
I wouldn't say no to that, Captain.
By the way, I have to ask. How are you holding up?
I won't deny that I'm in some pain, but I can manage. I'm sure the Chief will have it sorted soon enough.
Impressive, Lady Zulu. Tough as nails, sharp, and deadly with a broadside of guns.
Are you trying to embarrass me some more? We wouldn't be sitting here, alive, enjoying tea together if I couldn't count on you, Captain.
I feel much closer after what we went through. You are always my captain, but I hope you wouldn't mind if I considered you my friend, too.
I'd like that, Zulu. More tea?
For the record, I should add that the Neutrality Fleet Command is pleased, the Admiralty is ecstatic, and the crew is acutely aware of whom they have to thank for not being dead. If it matters.
You know, I don't need to hear that as badly as I would have a month or so ago... but, yes. It matters.
